Background.text: Usually children 6 years old or younger

Foreign_Body_Types.text:
Ear foreign body
Nasal foreign body
Ocular foreign body
Aspirated foreign body
GI
Ingested foreign body
Bezoar
Body packing
Esophageal foreign body removal with foley catheter
Rectal foreign body
Soft tissue foreign body

links.text: Esophageal foreign body removal with foley catheter

Foreign_Body_Types.text:
Ear foreign body
Nasal foreign body
Ocular foreign body
Aspirated foreign body
GI
Ingested foreign body
Bezoar

Rectal foreign body

links.text: Esophageal foreign body removal with foley catheter

Clinical_Features.text:
Caregiver often reports seeing child put something in the ear
Decreased hearing
or
otalgia
More common on right (hand dominant) side
May have otorrhea or bleeding
Foreign body contacting tympanic membrane can cause intractable
hiccups

External.text:
Auricular hematoma
Auricular perichondritis
Cholesteatoma
Contact dermatitis
Ear foreign body
Herpes zoster oticus
(Ramsay Hunt syndrome)
Malignant otitis externa
Otitis externa
Otomycosis
Tympanic membrane rupture
Otic barotrauma

Internal.text:
Acute otitis media
Bullous myringitis
Chronic otitis media
Mastoiditis

Inner/vestibular.text:
Labyrinthitis
,
vestibular neuritis
Meniere's disease
Sudden sensorineural hearing loss

Auricular hematoma
Auricular perichondritis
Cholesteatoma
Contact dermatitis
Ear foreign body
Herpes zoster oticus
(Ramsay Hunt syndrome)
Malignant otitis externa

Otic barotrauma

Internal.text:
Acute otitis media
Bullous myringitis
Chronic otitis media
Mastoiditis

Inner/vestibular.text:
Labyrinthitis
,
vestibular neuritis
Meniere's disease
Sudden sensorineural hearing loss

Evaluation.text:
Typically seen on visual inspection or otoscopy
Check other ear / nares

General_Removal_Options.text:
Irrigation
Contraindicated if suspected
TM perforation
, tympanostomy tubes, button battery, or vegetable parts (swells)
Body temperature sterile water or normal saline to avoid inducing nystagmus
Attach 14 or 16 ga IV catheter to 20-60 mL syringe
Can also utilize an infant nasogastric tube instead of an IV catheter, place tip of catheter next to TM, connect syringe and irrigate
Alligator forceps
Right angle tool / day hook
Scoop with curette (lighted curette helpful)
Schuknecht extractor (attaches to wall suction)
Dermabond on a swab stick
[1]
Allow glue to become tacky before inserting into canal
May use disposable ear speculum to shield canal so do not accidentally glue stick to ear canal

Antibiotics.text:
Consider
ofloxacin
or
ciprofloxacin
+/-
dexamethasone
if
perforated TM
or significant trauma to ear canal

Insects.text:
May wish to first kill (e.g., with mineral oil,
EtOH
, diluted hydrogen peroxide, or 2%
lidocaine
) prior to removal
In an in-vitro trial mineral oil was faster and more effective than other methods to kill cockroaches
[2]
Sometimes use of killing agents may make insects soft and mushy, thus making it more difficult to remove all pieces. In this case, may consider irrigation afterwards, to remove all parts. Or, may alternatively defer injection of liquid and prefer swift removal, if a viable option (e.g., with a compliant, non-pediatric patient)

Disposition.text:
Most patients with foreign body removal and no significant complications can be discharged
Consider urgent ENT consult/follow-up for TM injuries, retained FB, retained insect parts
Emergent ENT for all button batteries failing ED management
